sentence.text: In this study, we established fat cell differentiation as a therapeutic target for glioma treatment.
Expression of fat cell differentiation as well as regulation of proteasomal protein catabolic process-67 was higher in glioma tissues demonstrated by western blot and immunohistochemistry.

entity.text: regulation of proteasomal protein catabolic process

sentence.text: Then, the role of fat cell differentiation in migration and proliferation of glioma cells was investigated by conducting wound-healing, trans-well assay, cell counting activation of MAPK activity (neuron migration)-8, flow cytometry assay and colony formation analysis.

The data showed that interfering fat cell differentiation may inhibit the migration and proliferation of glioma cells by reducing expression of cyclin A, cyclin B1, cyclin D1, Vimentin, and N-integrin-mediated signaling pathway, and by increasing expression of E-cadherin.
Additionally, interfering fat cell differentiation may induce apoptosis of glioma cells by upregulating caspase-3 expression.

Furthermore, these in vitro findings were validated in vivo and the protein phosphorylation/2 and phosphorylation/positive regulation of protein phosphorylation signaling pathways were involved in fat cell differentiation-triggered migration and proliferation of glioma cells.
In an in vivo model, downregulation of fat cell differentiation suppressed tumor growth.

In conclusion, fat cell differentiation is closely associated with migration, proliferation, and apoptosis of glioma cells, and might be considered as a novel prognostic indicator in patients with gliomas
